content.title: Ely Wine Bar, wine tasting in the Georgian district

introduction.small: In the heart of Dublin, Ely Wine is a high end wine bar that brilliantly stands out from traditional Irish taverns.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Ely Wine Bar, wine tasting in the Georgian district

paragraphs.text:
Located two steps away from Dublin's St Stephen's Green park, Ely Wine Bar is now one of the iconic mainstays of the capital. It took up residence in a townhouse, typical of the Georgian district that was built from 1714 to 1820 by kings George I, II and III. With exposed grey brick walls, as well as wooden floors and furniture, the wine bar gives off an inviting feeling, ideal when one tastes great vintages.
The list presents a selection of about a hundred wines by the glass and five hundred bottles, sourced from European soil but also from the New World. Depending on your choice, let the sommelier pair your wine with accompanying dishes, all cooked from organic ingredients, like the beef carpaccio or the calamari with homemade aioli. Ely Wine Bar regularly offers wine tasting courses, a great opportunity to learn from great connoisseurs.

Ely Wine Bar
22 Ely Pl
Dublin 2

+353 (0)1 676 8986

www.elywinebar.ie ﻿

Menu: wine bottle from 27 EUR

content.title: L. Mulligan Grocer, gastronomic pub in a 200-year-old inn

introduction.small: Discover the L. Mulligan Grocer, an original spot in Dublin, between traditional pub and creative restaurant.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: L. Mulligan Grocer, gastronomic pub in a 200-year-old inn

paragraphs.text:
On the north bank of the Liffey River, L. Mulligan Grocer is always packed. This 200-year-old institution was once neglected but returned to its former glory, even becoming a must in Dublin. It retained the old-school pub look, with a black and red front, solid wood shared tables commonly found in 19th-century inns, old concrete tiles and period wooden floors.
In the kitchen, L. Milligan Grocer rather bets on creative and ambitious recipes, an approach that made it a spearhead for Irish “gastropubs”. The menus are housed in old children's books that come apart, presenting dishes inspired by traditional Irish gastronomy, with a touch of modernity. Served with a glass of beer, cider or whisky – to be enjoyed in moderation, of course – you shouldn't pass on the house special: the scotch egg, a soft-boiled egg wrapped in breaded sausage meat. Nothing better to discover genuine Dublin cuisine in all its subtlety!

L. Mulligan Grocer
18 Stoneybatter
Arran Quay
Dublin 7

+353 (0)1 670 9889

lmulligangrocer1.weebly.com

Menu: around 30 EUR

content.title: The Church, from morning to night

introduction.small: North of the River Liffey, The Church stands at the corner of Mary Street and Jervis Street. Converted into a place of tourism and entertainment, the church intrigues as much as it amuses.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Church, from morning to night

paragraphs.text:
In the shopping district of Dublin, a small church with large stained glass windows demands special attention. A spiral staircase climbs upward outside, within a large translucent column against the main building. This is a former place of worship built in the 18th century, the Church of St. Mary of Ireland, now completely restored and converted into a bar, restaurant and nightclub.

From the Irish fillet steak to the duo of seabass and clams, the Gallery restaurant charms you and the Cellar Bar enlivens you with its red and purple hues. When evening falls, The Church lights up with DJs or Irish bands, and the Dublin crowd gets moving. One of many unique cocktails in hand, you can dance until the end of the night, moving between the different spaces of the Church.

The Church – Café, Bar, Restaurant, Club & Tourist Attraction
Junction of Mary Street & Jervis Street
Dublin 1

+353 (0)1 828 0102

www.thechurch.ie

content.title: Tales and legends at the Leprechaun museum

introduction.small: In the heart of Dublin, the National Leprechaun Museum invites you to discover a small creature, a symbol of the country

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Tales and legends at the Leprechaun museum

paragraphs.text:
There are many Irish legends that tell the story of this little red-bearded, green-haired being. Smoking a pipe and wearing a shoemaker's apron, he cautiously watches over his cauldron of gold coins at the foot of a rainbow, promising fortune to the most acquisitive among us. Behind his grumpy and marginal personality, this fantastical character conceals his cunning!

At the National Leprechaun Museum, guided tours explore the mythical creatures of Ireland: leprechauns, elves and unicorns captivate you with magical stories and enchanting fables. Take part in the folklore of the island in this very first attraction devoted to Irish mythology. Your child within will appreciate the visit!

National Leprechaun Museum
Jervis Street
Dublin 1

+353 (0)1 873 3899

www.leprechaunmuseum.ie

content.title: Thornton's: natural Irish gastronomy

introduction.small: It's not by chance that Kevin Thornton, Ireland's first two-starred chef, opened his restaurant just in front of St. Stephen's Green.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Thornton's: natural Irish gastronomy

paragraphs.text:
For more than 25 years, Kevin Thornton has practised an elementary gastronomy that pays homage to the moors and shores of his homeland: ‘A sorrel leaf is blown by the damp wind […] a flame sears a fillet—Earth, Wind, Water, Fire.'

On your plate, the complex ecosystem of Irish nature is respected and enhanced by gastronomic excellence: peat smoked Atlantic salmon fermented in algae; wood pigeon with mashed carrot and juniper sauce… Even the way these dishes are composed graphically evokes Irish landscapes.

The restaurant interior is in the brown, beige, chocolate, and caramel of many chic Dublin interiors. But here, the comfort is more refined and the materials more natural. This is a gastronomic experience as pure and as spontaneous as Ireland.

Thornton's Restaurant
1st, The Fitzwilliam Hotel
128 St Stephen's Green
Dublin 2

+353 (0)1 478 7008

www.thorntonsrestaurant.com

Menu: around 50 EUR

content.title: The Merrion Hotel: a typical Dubliner mansion

introduction.small: Its austere facade does not do justice to this Georgian house, built in the 18th century, and among the best located and renovated in Dublin.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Merrion Hotel: a typical Dubliner mansion

paragraphs.text:
The liveried staff enhances the hospitality at the Merrion Hotel with a smile. Access to the rooms is via a glass roof, which also overlooks the garden, a rare haven of greenery in Dublin. And the hotel's tiled pool is an unexpected oasis! The hotel is famous for its teatime. It is so popular that regulars hasten to get here.

This is an opportunity to take hot, strong tea and eat local pastries in front of the warm fireplace in the green room, while a harpist weaves melodies from his gracious instrument. The hotel has several works of art, about which the staff would be happy, even honoured, to tell you.

The Merrion Hotel
Merrion Street Upper
Dublin 2

+353 (1) 603 0600

www.merrionhotel.com

Rooms: from 250 EUR

content.title: Bring your wine and your vinyl to the Vintage Kitchen

introduction.small: An old record player that never stops playing vinyl in a cosy atmosphere where red wine and vegetables crowd the tables: welcome to the Vintage Kitchen.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Bring your wine and your vinyl to the Vintage Kitchen

paragraphs.text:
The single room is small, only big enough to seat 20. The decoration is made up of mottled trinkets picked up at garage sales and arranged somewhat haphazardly on broad blue walls. Since the ingredients depend on what small local producers in the Leinster region have in stock, it is not impossible that you order a dish that disappears from the menu the next day. Like truffle and kale rice with sautéed vegetables, grilled pumpkin seeds and a green garlic mash, which come and go from the menu. There is always a ‘little something' that will delight your appetite. Like its clientele, the service is dynamic and relaxed. And don't be surprised to see a group of Trinity College students studying here after evening classes.

The Vintage Kitchen
7 Poolbeg Street
Dublin

+353 (0)1 679 8705

www.thevintagekitchen.ie

Menu: around 20 EUR

content.title: Walk through the ruins of the windy and green hills of Glendalough

introduction.small: Gleann Dá Loch said that the ‘valley of the two lakes' constitutes 1,500 years of history scattered in the weeds of a huge valley that fought over by clans as salubrious as the Celtic winds.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Walk through the ruins of the windy and green hills of Glendalough

paragraphs.text:
Although only 50 kilometres separate Dublin from this valley, when you get off the bus, you have the striking feeling of being far away from any form of civilisation.

Wherever your gaze falls, you see green, green, and green again. There is a small village with weathered buildings nestled in the crevice of this glen. You will reach the windswept ruins, in severe cold and under a pale sun, via a small wooden bridge. A weary, round tower indicates that successive invasions have spared the local monastery. Take the grassy road that meanders towards the monastery, or head to the village cemetery. There, you will see a sparse forest dotted with tombstones and Celtic crosses. Look up and you can see the silhouettes of hikers venturing into Upper Lake and Lower Lake. Forgotten there as reflective discs of an unknown civilisation, the lakes are dark blue, icy and mesmerising.

Glendalough
Bray, Co.
Wicklow

+353 (1) 404 45325

www.heritageireland.ie

content.title: Schoolhouse Hotel: the luxury of the Anglo-Saxon boarding school

introduction.small: If you are a Harry Potter fan who has always secretly wanted to stay just one night at Hogwarts, the Schoolhouse Hotel might be the place for you.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Schoolhouse Hotel: the luxury of the Anglo-Saxon boarding school

paragraphs.text:
Located just 10 minutes from Dublin's city centre, the Schoolhouse is an old school that has been renovated into a hotel. When you arrive you will be treated like new boarders at a large English school.

The wood-panelled lounges are bathed in warm light. In the background, an Irish melody plays, and deep armchairs await sleepers and readers. Three roaring fireplaces convey the same convivial, centuries-old ambience they have done since these were classrooms. If there were any studying still going on here, though, it would be on the subject of comfort. On weekend evenings, however, the common room takes on a pub atmosphere. But your sleep will not be disturbed, because revellers know the school rules by heart! Your rooms, where the beds are as huge as those of one's childhood, are well maintained—and your sleep as well!

Schoolhouse Hotel
Grand Canal Dock District
2-8 Northumberland Rd
Dublin 4

+353 (0)1 667 5014

www.schoolhousehotel.com

Rooms: from 99 EUR

content.title: Chapter One: edible poetry in Ireland

introduction.small: From its black oval sign that enlivens the imagination and the dishes described in handwritten typography on the menu, it takes a lot of character and a very small appetite to resist Chapter One.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Chapter One: edible poetry in Ireland

paragraphs.text:
The establishment is located a few steps down into the cellar.

Open the door and the cold of Dublin's streets vanishes. The decor reminds you immediately of a refined and cosy reading lounge, while the rooms are in shades of brown and green that subtly evoke the Irish landscape. It is that passion for the land and attention to the sacredness of the changing seasons that gives form to the Michelin-starred cuisine. Vegetables, cheeses, and heathland game are brought together and showcased alongside pumpkin cream, while pheasant hen and Jerusalem artichoke sauce combine deliciously.

A network of small local producers supplies the restaurant. And there are pleasantly surprising local wines: Irish grapes are as tempestuous as the wild west coast of Ireland!

Chapter One
Rotunda District
18-19 Parnell Square
Dublin 1

+353 (0)1 873 2266

www.chapteronerestaurant.com

Menu: about 60 EUR

content.title: Dublin Writers Museum: an overview of Irish literary heritage

introduction.small: ‘When I die Dublin will be written in my heart.' James Joyce's touching words illustrate the intimate relationship the greatest Irish writers have always maintained with their capital.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Dublin Writers Museum: an overview of Irish literary heritage

paragraphs.text:
Dublin has honoured its writers by erecting an intimate museum in their memory, located right in the city's heart, literally and figuratively. You will discover, or rediscover, here, in a more private way, the life of the great prose writers of Irish history through a large collection of artefacts that belonged to them: various personal items such as James Joyce's piano, as well as confidential letters, portraits, and manuscripts, such as a first edition of Dracula. Visitors can't touch, but reading is highly recommended! Jonathan Swift, Oscar Wilde, Samuel Beckett… the exhibition dwells on each of these figures in chronological order, organised by literary movement. Constant recontextualising ensures continuity and the understanding of these authors and their works. Note that the museum has a small stage where you can enjoy, nourished by your newly acquired knowledge, eloquent and enchanting readings of the most beautiful, incantatory prose that Irish writers have created.

Dublin Writers Museum
Rotunda District
18-19 Parnell Square North
Dublin 1

+353 (0)1 872 2077

www.visitdublin.com/see-do/details/dublin-writers-museum

content.title: Clontarf Castle Hotel: the most modern castle hotel in Ireland

introduction.small: The Clontarf Castle is the successful marriage of the timeless charm of an Irish castle and the high standards of a modern palace hotel.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Clontarf Castle Hotel: the most modern castle hotel in Ireland

paragraphs.text:
When you arrive, take the time to enjoy the majesty of the building, whose foundations date back to the 12th century. There is the same harmony in the lobby: the decor is a savvy mix of antique furniture and decorative pieces alongside contemporary elements. The castle is full of surprising details: above the reception, a paragon of a deer's head is enthroned; in a corner, a knight's suit of armour stands guard. Although flowered tapestry and canopy beds are de rigueur, the rooms are less decorated but more favourable to the relaxation of the mind and senses. Without being formal, the polite, effective service is worthy of its setting, because, here, you are not just anyone.

Clontarf Castle Hotel
Clontarf District
Castle Avenue
Dublin 3

+353 (0)1 833 2321

www.clontarfcastle.ie

Rooms: from 105 EUR

content.title: Dublinia: the Vikings in flesh and bone are the friendliest in Ireland

introduction.small: This heritage centre located in the heart of the medieval city takes you on a journey through the history of Dublin right back to its origins.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Dublinia: the Vikings in flesh and bone are the friendliest in Ireland

paragraphs.text:
Following a chronological and thematic order, the centre focuses on three major aspects of the Irish capital: the Viking invasions, life in medieval Dublin, and archaeological finds. Never in a museum has play and immersion been so well placed at the service of learning. With the Vikings, learn the runic alphabet by writing your name in runes.

Learn about the art of engraving coins from a Viking blacksmith, who is as blunt as the axe in his belt. In comparison, the daily life of Dubliners in medieval times will seem much less friendly! Browse its alleyways, infested by the Black Death, or the stands of those cruel fairs that set up their striped tents at the unhygienic markets of the time. Meanwhile, children can detail a huge scale-model of Dublin in the 13th century. The third floor is no exception to the rule and will deliver the daily life and secrets surrounding the ‘History Hunters'. Learn what gives rise to vocations... or conversions!

Dublinia
Christchurch
St Michaels Hill
Dublin 8

+353 (0)1 679 4611

www.dublinia.ie

content.title: The Shelbourne: the most comfortable heritage monument in Dublin

introduction.small: The bubbly luxury and lively friendliness at the Shelbourne will almost make you forget the rainy, windy streets of Dublin.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Shelbourne: the most comfortable heritage monument in Dublin

paragraphs.text:
Overlooking St. Stephen's Green, the Shelbourne is a Victorian-style building.

Between its walls, lined now with master paintings, historicity is synonymous with hospitality. The small museum tells you about the great moments of Irish independence. Upon entering, to your right, a vast green room in the Renaissance style is bathed in a dark atmosphere conducive to reading. Outside, pearly carriages in procession return from their excursions around St. Stephen's. The hotel combines to perfection the charm of its lustrous past and the requirements of modernity. Rich with a host of attentions, padded and lined throughout with fabrics, the Shelbourne's rooms are among the most comfortable places to spend the night in Dublin.

Time in this sweet cocoon seems to magically stand still.

The Shelbourne Dublin, A Renaissance Hotel
27 St. Stephen's Green
Dublin 2

+353 (0)1 663 4500

www.marriott.fr/hotels/travel/dubbr-the-shelbourne-dublin-a-renaissance-hotel

Rooms: from 208 EUR

content.title: A studious promenade in the halls of Trinity College

introduction.small: The oldest and most prestigious university in Ireland conceals many treasures, including a campus on which you can pretend to be a student for an afternoon.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A studious promenade in the halls of Trinity College

paragraphs.text:
With no fewer than 19 hectares, you are free to browse the Trinity College campus at your leisure. There are also students who know the campus inside and out, and who provide guided tours. Their historical anecdotes and trivia about the university will make the tour meaningful and fun. End of the match, on the windy college grounds! Enjoy the show, or head to the Old Library where you will find two big surprises.

The first: the Book of Kells, a masterpiece of the art of calligraphy by Celtic monks, whose illuminations seem enchanted! And, the Long Room, your second surprise, which contains every Irish and English book published since the 18th century. The library seems to have materialised from a fairy engraving, or the madness of a magician. The air is redolent with the heady perfume of old parchment and polished woodwork. No chatter! The marble busts of the great figures of human knowledge guard this basilica of learning. Like teachers, their stern expressions suppress the noisiness of errant travellers.

Trinity College
College Green
Dublin 2

+353 (0)1 896 1000

www.tcd.ie/

content.title: The Winding Stair: a literary bistro with a splash of poetry

introduction.small: The transformation of this old Irish bookshop, located near the Liffey, into a literary bistro has something to delight both the gourmet and the poet lying dormant within you.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Winding Stair: a literary bistro with a splash of poetry

paragraphs.text:
Inscribed in gold lettering on a dark green facade with windows overflowing with books: ‘The Winding Stair'. Connoisseurs will recognise the reference: a famous poem by William Yeats.

Climb the spiral staircase that leads to the dining room: Colin the waiter welcomes you into the organised disorder of small chairs and tables. Shelves crowded with multi-coloured books adorn the white-brick walls. Have a look. Who knows what you'll find! The chalkboards reveal a rustic kitchen that showcases regional products. Their very names are the names of Irish dishes. Like Ballinwillin's black pudding terrine. Or a platter of Irish charcuterie that marries Fingal Ferguson's cold-cuts with homemade bread. So, words or food?

The Winding Stair
40 Lower Ormond Quay
Dublin 1

+353 (0)1 872 7320

www.winding-stair.com

Menu: around 20 EUR

content.title: An Irish stroll on St. Stephen's Green

introduction.small: St. Stephen's Green is a favourite park of Dubliner families and Trinity College students, too.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: An Irish stroll on St. Stephen's Green

paragraphs.text:
In the late afternoon in any season, after a day of travel or work, it does wonders to stroll through this nine-hectare Victorian park. Once past the arch that marks the main entrance, the feeling of open space is followed promptly by a feeling of relaxation. Here, on the rich, wet lawns, groups of students converse while eating lunch.

There, a couple of young Dubliners on a bench read under the shade of an old oak.

On Saturday, there is dancing to the tunes from the kiosk. Remember that the park is full of secret pathways that justify its exploration. In the northwest corner, a ‘blind' flower garden challenges you to recognise the different smells. Further north, the murmur of a waterfall should lead you to the coveted edges of a body of water animated by the indolent dance of birds. Elsewhere, a promenade along the outer edges of the park is lined with statues of figures from Irish folklore.

Saint Stephen's Green
St Stephen's Green
Dublin 2

+353 (0)1 475 7816

www.heritageireland.ie

content.title: St. Patrick's Cathedral: the Dublin seat of the patron saint of Ireland

introduction.small: Although a little austere at first because of its grey granite blocks, this cathedral actually hides one of the most beautiful places of Irish Anglican worship.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: St. Patrick's Cathedral: the Dublin seat of the patron saint of Ireland

paragraphs.text:
Ard Eaglais Naomh Pádraig (the Irish name for the cathedral) is one of the main settings in The Tudors, the famous history-TV series that addresses the very tormented life of the young Henry VIII.

Once inside, you'll understand why: the colours are central, forming an amber light that warms the soul. There is sparkling stained glass, whose dreamy tones and fabulous style filter a brighter light than life. On the ground, there is another spectacle of medieval tiles with geometric figures that leaves many travellers speechless. Finally, above the choir and its solid wooden pews hang two rows of banners adorned with the coat of arms of the Knights of St. Patrick. On choir days, Gaelic songs make the granite resound, giving a fairly accurate picture of the cathedral at the height of its glory.

Your visit will conclude with a trip into the depths of the monument: the crypt! Underground, there awaits a maze of safe, low galleries, which follow one another in the darkness, the ornate tombs... and the fluorescent key rings in the gift shop!

St. Patrick's Cathedral
St. Patrick's Close
Dublin 8

+353 (0)1 453 9472

www.stpatrickscathedral.ie

content.title: The Long Hall: beer-drinking in a Victorian atmosphere

introduction.small: If you had to personify this pub, which is almost as old as Dublin, it would be a man with a beard as frothy and amber-hued as the selection of beers on tap at the bar.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Long Hall: beer-drinking in a Victorian atmosphere

paragraphs.text:
At this bar you can enjoy the best pint of Guinness in Dublin. Go figure! The Long Hall is undoubtedly one of the best-stocked Dublin pubs. Which is no small feat!

Its selection is second to none with brown, pale, red, white, and rare local ales you will not find anywhere else. This is a legendary pub, but in terms of decor, it is like a Victorian chapel! There are huge mirrors, carved wood-panelled stalls, cosy and plush, and fragrant with barley as evening falls.

Hang on to your bar stool in the evenings because it gets crowded! Except for the television, which shows rugby day and night, you would think yourself in 19th-century Dublin.

The Long Hall
51 South Great George's Street
Dublin 2

+353 (0)1 475 1590

Menu (drinks only): around 5 EUR

content.title: The Hugh Lane: an artistic interlude to your stay in Dublin

introduction.small: Besides being pleasant to visit, this little modern and contemporary art museum has a rare concentration of masterpieces, both international and Irish.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Hugh Lane: an artistic interlude to your stay in Dublin

paragraphs.text:
Plunge into the darkness of a room with stained-glass windows and let us tell you about the interpretation of ‘The Eve of St. Agnes' by Henry Clarke, glass artist of the 20th century.

Then find yourself transported as you go from room to room in which 50 paintings follow one another. The silence in this museum is rarely broken. It is a journey between portraits and landscapes, punctuated by an organisation that works intelligently to match them. Many masterpieces, among those of Manet, Renoir, and Degas, dot the course. Some side rooms offer digressions, welcome to those who wish to deepen a theme. At the end of this parade of paintings, the exhibition focuses on the work of the Dublin-born painter, Francis Bacon. In this dark, cramped space, which aptly captures the feeling of unease that permeates the work of the artist, you can admire in great detail the reconstitution of the London studio where Bacon painted. This domestic metaphor of chaos, which might give you a twinge of a headache, is accompanied by interactive animations that throw much light on the mystery of this painter.

Dublin City Gallery The Hugh Lane
Rotunda District
Charelmont House
Parnell Square North
Dublin 1

+353 (0)1 222 5550

www.hughlane.ie

content.title: Aberdeen Lodge: a haven of peace on the Celtic Sea

introduction.small: At Aberdeen Lodge, the smell of the salty coastal wind and biscuits baking in the oven constitute the fragrance of hospitality.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Aberdeen Lodge: a haven of peace on the Celtic Sea

paragraphs.text:
This hotel is a typical Irish seaside mansion. This peaceful haven of blue, yellow, and green is run by a very hospitable Dublin family. Missing brunch to go on a trip to Glendalough? No problem, they'll make sandwiches for you. The warm, caring house perfectly reflects this hospitality. Brunch is served in front of the large fireplace in the blonde dining room where Paws, the cat, spends most of his time. There are flowers everywhere, even in the nest-like rooms, where a light-yellow-and-snow-white palette and wood tones prevail. Aberdeen Lodge also offers sports activities, including golf and cricket! Otherwise, put on your scarf and head toward the windy Celtic Sea, just steps away!

Aberdeen Lodge
Sandymount District
53-55 Park Avenue
Dublin 4

+353 (0)1 283 8155

www.aberdeen-lodge.com

Rooms: from 99 EUR

content.title: The sacred and artistic wonders of the Chester Beatty Library

introduction.small: You would not believe that this building on the outskirts of Dublin Castle houses a collection of the most beautiful expressions of the human imagination.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The sacred and artistic wonders of the Chester Beatty Library

paragraphs.text:
'Filled with the treasures of numerous ancient civilisations [...] stunning in beauty due to its miniatures and paintings.' It is in these enthusiastic terms that the Director of the National Library of Ireland describes Chester Beatty's collection, considered one of the most beautiful in the world in terms of Islamic and Oriental art.

The exhibition rooms are immersed in a comfortable dimness that allows you to focus on the works, which are enhanced by well-judged lighting. The rare objects compose a veritable imaginarium: a series of prints tells you the story of a Japanese legend, pitting samurai against demons; an early premium microscope, which at first seems incongruous, reveals the smallest ideograms drawn by a human hand; an antique collection of Asian etchings makes modern perfume bottles pale in comparison.

The diversity of stories and their modes of expression are such that, on leaving, you will feel the pleasant impression of having been under the influence of the fantastic phenomena of a magic lantern!

Chester Beatty Library
Dublin Castle
Dublin 2

+353 (0)1 407 0750

www.cbl.ie

content.title: The Guinness Storehouse, or the temple of beer to the strains of a golden harp

introduction.small: It took Dubliners little more than a century to grant the Guinness Storehouse the status of a national monument.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Guinness Storehouse, or the temple of beer to the strains of a golden harp

paragraphs.text:
The warehouse is located in the heart of the legendary St. James Brewery, founded by Arthur Guinness, father of the brand, in 1759. The area immediately conveys an ambience and context: modern buildings and wide avenues give way to huge constructions of brick typical of the Industrial era. Upon entering the warehouse, experts of the pint will smile, for before them will be a glass atrium in the shape of a pint of Guinness.

Welcome to the national temple of ‘black', as the Irish affectionately call it! Each of its seven floors focuses on a very specific aspect of Guinness beer, from production to distribution, in an updated industrial setting that evokes a James Joyce short story. Temporary shows, like ‘improvised' Irish dance, will make you smile or dance! Your ascension, which lasts about two hours, ends with a sizeable reward: a panoramic view of Dublin and the green velvet valleys of the Wicklow Mountains.

Guinness Storehouse
The Liberties District
St James's Gate
Dublin 8

+353 (0)1 408 4800

www.guinness-storehouse.com/en
